question.text: People living at sea level have around 5 million RBC per cubic millimetre of their blood, whereas those living at an altitude of 5400 metres have around 8 million. This is because at high altitude,

options.text: Atmospheric O<sub>2</sub> level is less and hence more RBCs are needed to absorb the required amount of O<sub>2</sub> to survive
There is more UV radiation which enhances RBC production
People eat more nutritive food, therefore more RBCs are formed
People get pollution - free air to breathe and more oxygen is available.

solution.text: At the altitude of 5400 meters, the low atmospheric pressure of O<sub>2</sub> will be too low so the solubility of oxygen in the blood will be very less hence the oxygen carried by each RBC will be too less. However, to fulfill the oxygen requirement of the body blood has to carry more oxygen to the body tissue, and this done by the increased number of RBCs.
